nodes.text: A J48/C4.5 decision tree model can effectively predict diabetes status from the Pima Indian dataset
We built a decision tree classifier using the J48 implementation (C4.5) in the WEKA environment
The study used the Pima Indian Diabetes dataset (768 female subjects, 8 input numeric attributes, binary class: tested_positive or tested_negative)
Attribute selection during tree induction used entropy and information gain; the attribute with highest gain selected for splits
Model performance was evaluated using a confusion matrix reporting true positives, true negatives, false positives, false negatives, and derived accuracy
The J48 model achieved overall accuracy of 84.1146% on the dataset
Confusion matrix counts: true positives 468, true negatives 178, false positives 32, false negatives 90
Compared to an existing method, the proposed J48 approach improved accuracy by 0.48% while increasing model build time by 0.02 seconds (from 0.03s to 0.05s)
Entropy and gain calculations for attributes show plasma glucose has the highest information gain (gain = 0.1332) compared to BMI and pregnancy
The Pima dataset contains missing or zero values in several attributes (e.g., 5 glucose=0, 11 BMI=0, 28 diastolic BP=0, 192 skinfold=0, 140 insulin=0); deleting these reduces usable cases to 392
Conclusion: J48 decision tree in WEKA provides a reasonably accurate predictive model for diabetes on the Pima dataset, supported by entropy-based splitting and confusion matrix evaluation
Recommendation / Future enhancement: handle or remove missing values and test models in different environments to obtain more reliable predictions
